case_studies.title: Psychosocial Support for an Adolescent with Severe Nutritional Disorder and Food Allergies
case_studies.vignette: A 14-year-old girl from a semi-urban area in India presents with fatigue, recurrent abdominal pain, and poor school performance over the past 6 months. She has a history of multiple food allergies, including cow’s milk, wheat, and peanuts, and her diet has been restricted accordingly. Her mother reports difficulty in finding affordable and culturally acceptable substitutes for these foods, leading to frequent arguments at home about her eating habits. On examination, her BMI is 15.5 kg/m² (<3rd percentile), and she has pallor and mild angular cheilitis. A recent hemoglobin test revealed 9.2 g/dL. She appears withdrawn during the consultation, expressing frustration about feeling different from her peers and struggling with social isolation. The family has limited access to dietary counseling services and is unsure how to manage her nutritional needs while avoiding allergens.
case_studies.learning_objective: Understand multidisciplinary approaches to psychosocial and nutritional challenges in adolescents with severe food allergies.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Role of physical activity in adolescent weight management: counselling and programmatic integration
subtopics.concept: Physical activity plays a pivotal role in adolescent weight management, complementing dietary measures and offering extensive health benefits. Counseling adolescents on physical activity requires a personalized approach that considers both the quantity and quality of exercise, alongside strategies to incorporate activity into their daily routines. Globally, including in India, physical inactivity is a significant concern, with the World Health Organization (WHO) estimating that approximately 81% of school-going adolescents aged 11–17 fail to meet the recommended 60 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity daily. This sedentary behavior contributes to rising obesity rates and associated health issues. Pediatricians and healthcare providers must actively promote physical activity as a core lifestyle habit, employing motivational counseling techniques and leveraging programmatic initiatives, such as school sports or community programs, to ensure adolescents not only understand the importance of exercise but also have access to opportunities for physical activity. When counseling adolescents for weight management, discussions about physical activity should be framed positively, emphasizing enjoyment rather than framing exercise as a chore or punishment. Identifying activities the adolescent enjoys—such as sports (football, basketball, badminton), dance, swimming, cycling, or brisk walking with friends—is crucial. Counselors should assess the adolescent’s baseline activity levels and interests by asking questions like, “What do you like to do for fun?” or “Do you enjoy any sports or outdoor games?” Any movement is better than none, and even activities such as walking or biking to school, participating in physical education classes, or doing active household chores contribute to daily physical activity. The goal should align with WHO guidelines: at least 60 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity daily for 5–17-year-olds, with muscle- and bone-strengthening exercises included at least three days per week. Moderate activity involves a level where one can talk but not sing, while vigorous activity limits speech to a few words without pausing for breath. Examples of muscle-strengthening activities include squats, modified push-ups, yoga, or climbing. Counselors should address common barriers, such as misconceptions that only structured exercise (e.g., gym workouts) counts. Creative suggestions, such as walking or cycling short distances, taking stairs instead of elevators, or dancing at home, can help adolescents accumulate activity throughout the day. For those unable to do 60 minutes at once, breaking it into three 20-minute sessions is equally effective. Technology integration, such as fitness apps, step-count goals (e.g., 10,000 steps/day), or active video games, can further motivate adolescents. Physical activity aids weight management by burning calories, building muscle (which enhances basal metabolism), improving insulin sensitivity, and supporting psychological well-being, which can reduce stress-eating. Explaining these benefits in simple terms, such as “Exercise makes you fitter and stronger, and helps your body burn food better so it doesn’t turn into extra weight,” can resonate well with adolescents.

case_studies.title: Adolescent Weight Concerns and Physical Activity Counseling in India
case_studies.vignette: A 14-year-old girl from a semi-urban area in India presents to the pediatric outpatient clinic with concerns about weight gain over the last year. Her mother reports a sedentary lifestyle, with the adolescent spending most of her time on schoolwork or her smartphone. The girl mentions feeling self-conscious about her weight and avoids participating in physical education classes at school. On examination, her BMI is at the 95th percentile for her age and sex. Vital signs reveal blood pressure at 120/80 mmHg and a resting heart rate of 84 bpm. When asked about her interests, she expresses a fondness for dancing but feels too embarrassed to join dance classes. Her school has limited sports facilities, and her neighborhood lacks safe spaces for outdoor activities. She has no history of significant medical issues, and her dietary habits include frequent consumption of packaged snacks and sugary beverages.
case_studies.learning_objective: Understand the role of physical activity in adolescent weight management and strategies for personalized counseling and programmatic integration.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Impact of socioeconomic and psychosocial factors on adolescent dietary choices
subtopics.concept: Adolescent dietary choices are influenced by a complex interplay of socioeconomic and psychosocial factors, particularly in the diverse Indian context. Socioeconomic status (SES) significantly impacts food availability, affordability, and dietary patterns. Adolescents from lower-income families often face limited access to nutrient-dense foods such as fruits, milk, and meats due to cost constraints, leading them to rely on cheaper staples like rice, roti, or calorie-dense foods such as fried snacks and sugar-sweetened beverages. This dietary pattern contributes to the dual burden of undernutrition, due to deficiencies in vitamins and minerals, and obesity, driven by the consumption of processed foods high in sugar and fat. For instance, a low-income rural adolescent girl may subsist on rice with salt and oil or watery dal, resulting in nutritional deficiencies, while an urban high-SES adolescent may overconsume fast foods and sugary drinks, leading to overweight or obesity. Notably, research highlights that overweight and obesity prevalence is higher among adolescents from wealthier families, likely due to lifestyle transitions, greater access to high-calorie foods, and cultural habits such as eating out or ordering food, which increase fat and salt intake. Conversely, food insecurity in low-SES households can lead to meal skipping or reliance on starchy staples, with occasional indulgence in energy-dense foods as a treat, creating a “feast and famine” cycle that paradoxically promotes fat deposition. Urban-rural disparities further compound dietary differences. Urban adolescents generally have greater exposure to convenience foods, advertisements, and obesogenic environments, including proximity to fast-food outlets and school canteens. Urban poor adolescents often rely on cheap street foods like pakoras, samosas, and sweetened drinks, while rural adolescents consume more traditional diets when available. Education levels also influence nutrition knowledge; adolescents from educated families may have better awareness of healthy eating, though knowledge does not always translate to action. For example, high-SES adolescents may understand the risks of soda consumption but still drink it daily due to peer influence and availability. Effective interventions must be tailored to SES contexts: improving access to affordable nutritious foods in low-SES settings through midday meals, supplementation, and food fortification, while moderating excess and reducing junk food appeal in high-SES settings. Psychosocial factors, such as family environment, also play a critical role, as adolescents typically consume what is available at home.

case_studies.title: Impact of Socioeconomic and Psychosocial Factors on Adolescent Dietary Choices
case_studies.vignette: A 14-year-old girl from a rural village in India presents with persistent fatigue, dizziness, and difficulty concentrating in school over the past month. Her mother reports that the family struggles financially, often skipping meals or relying on rice with salt and oil as the primary diet. The girl admits to occasionally eating fried snacks from a local vendor when she has some pocket money. On examination, she appears pale and has a BMI of 16.5 kg/m². Vitals are stable: BP 100/70 mmHg, HR 88 bpm. A hemoglobin test reveals 8.5 g/dL. The mother mentions that the family prioritizes food quantity over quality due to affordability concerns, and the girl feels pressured to perform well academically despite her physical symptoms.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Addressing nutrition-related complications in adolescents: anemia, stunting, and metabolic syndrome
subtopics.concept: Addressing nutrition-related complications in adolescents, including anemia, stunting, and metabolic syndrome, requires a structured approach to prevention and management. Early complications often stem from inadequate nutrition, leading to anemia, stunting, and early signs of metabolic dysregulation such as rapid weight gain or unhealthy eating behaviors. Late complications include severe anemia (Hb <7 g/dL), established stunting with long-term growth and cognitive impacts, and metabolic syndrome manifesting as obesity-related comorbidities like type 2 diabetes, hypertension, fatty liver disease, or cardiovascular risks. Red-flag warning signs include sudden weight loss, obsessive food-related behaviors indicative of eating disorders, rapid BMI changes (e.g., crossing from the 75th to 90th percentile), and symptoms of relative energy deficiency in athletes, such as amenorrhea or stress fractures. The pathophysiology underlying these complications varies. Anemia often results from iron deficiency, compounded by poor dietary intake or helminth infections. Stunting reflects chronic undernutrition during critical growth periods, while metabolic syndrome arises from excess calorie intake and sedentary lifestyles, leading to insulin resistance and systemic inflammation. Early detection and bedside monitoring are essential. Regular growth monitoring, including plotting BMI and height, can identify growth faltering or rapid weight gain. Screening programs, such as annual anemia camps for adolescent girls, laboratory tests for vitamin deficiencies in high-risk populations, and questionnaires to detect unhealthy weight control practices, are critical secondary prevention strategies. For athletes, monitoring menstrual regularity and energy balance can prevent progression to tertiary complications. Escalation of care depends on the severity of the condition. Adolescents with severe anemia (Hb <7 g/dL) may require hospitalization and transfusion, followed by iron supplementation and dietary counseling to prevent recurrence. Overweight teens with established type 2 diabetes or hypertension require medical management, such as metformin or antihypertensives, alongside structured diet and exercise plans to control obesity and prevent further complications like kidney damage or cardiovascular disease. Definitive management also includes life-skills training in schools, such as teaching gardening, cooking healthy recipes, and reading nutrition labels, to foster long-term healthy habits. Follow-up care involves ensuring adherence to dietary and medical interventions, regular monitoring of growth and metabolic parameters, and ongoing education to sustain preventive behaviors.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Clinical management of adolescent undernutrition: criteria for admission and discharge / Algorithm for triaging adolescents with severe malnutrition: outpatient vs inpatient care
subtopics.concept: Clinical management of adolescent undernutrition, particularly in the context of eating disorders (EDs) such as anorexia nervosa (AN), bulimia nervosa (BN), and binge-eating disorder (BED), requires clear criteria for admission, stabilization, and discharge. Admission and escalation criteria focus on vital signs, hydration status, neurological symptoms, and evidence of bleeding. Hospitalization is warranted for adolescents presenting with significant bradycardia (<50 bpm), hypotension (<90/60 mmHg), or electrolyte disturbances, as these may indicate severe malnutrition and associated risks such as cardiac arrest. Signs of dehydration, including orthostatic tachycardia or dizziness upon standing, further support the need for inpatient care. Neurological symptoms such as fatigue, dizziness, or hypothermia, alongside physical findings like lanugo hair, acrocyanosis, and edema in AN, or Russell’s sign and parotid hypertrophy in BN, are critical indicators of severity. Bleeding-related concerns, such as anemia or leukopenia due to marrow suppression, should also be evaluated. Initial laboratory investigations include a complete blood count (CBC) to assess for anemia or leukopenia, serum electrolytes to identify hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis (from vomiting), or acidosis (from laxative abuse), and liver enzymes, which may be elevated due to starvation or bingeing. Thyroid function tests often reveal euthyroid sick syndrome in malnourished adolescents. Electrocardiograms (ECG) should be performed to detect prolonged QT intervals, which are a concern in AN. Stabilization steps prioritize nutritional rehabilitation and medical stability. Refeeding must be carefully monitored to prevent refeeding syndrome, with attention to correcting electrolyte imbalances and addressing bradycardia or hypotension. Coordination with mental health professionals is essential for addressing the psychological aspects of EDs. Thresholds for pediatric intensive care unit (PICU) admission are not explicitly stated in the source but may be inferred for cases with severe cardiovascular instability, profound electrolyte disturbances, or life-threatening complications. Discharge and review triggers are not specified in the source. However, ongoing outpatient care should include monitoring weight trends, nutritional intake, and mental health status, ensuring the adolescent achieves medical stability and engages in psychotherapy for long-term recovery.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Monitoring nutritional status in adolescents: frequency, methods, and follow-up strategies / Monitoring and follow-up strategies for adolescent nutrition programs
subtopics.concept: Monitoring nutritional status in adolescents involves implementing preventive strategies at three levels: primary, secondary, and tertiary prevention. Primary prevention aims to avert nutritional problems before they arise by promoting healthy behaviors and environments for all adolescents. This includes ensuring food security and access to a balanced diet, such as strengthening public distribution systems to provide sufficient grains and pulses to families with adolescents. Universal fortification of staples, such as iodized salt to prevent iodine deficiency and cognitive deficits, and iron-fortified rice in government feeding programs to reduce anemia, are key measures. Prophylactic deworming every six months in endemic regions prevents helminth-induced malnutrition. Health education campaigns, like "eat right and play hard," encourage adolescents to adopt balanced diets and daily exercise to combat both undernutrition and overnutrition. Life-skills training in schools, such as teaching gardening, cooking healthy recipes, and reading nutrition labels, fosters long-term healthy habits. Secondary prevention focuses on early detection and prompt intervention to halt the progression of nutritional problems. Annual anemia screening camps for adolescent girls, followed by iron supplementation for those found anemic, prevent mild anemia from becoming severe and causing cognitive or growth impairments. Growth monitoring through BMI and height assessments in schools or pediatric clinics can identify early growth faltering or rapid weight gain, enabling timely counseling. For example, intervening when an adolescent's BMI crosses from the 75th to the 90th percentile can prevent obesity. Screening for eating disorders, such as recognizing warning signs like sudden weight loss or obsessive food-related behaviors, allows early referral and intervention. In sports, nutritional screening of student athletes, including checks for relative energy deficiency signs like irregular periods in female athletes, prevents progression to complications such as stress fractures or amenorrhea. Laboratory screenings for vitamin deficiencies in high-risk communities and questionnaires to identify unhealthy weight control practices also fall under secondary prevention. Tertiary prevention addresses established nutritional-related diseases to reduce their impact and prevent further complications. For adolescents with severe anemia (Hb <7), hospitalization and transfusion are required, followed by a plan to prevent recurrence. Overweight adolescents who develop type 2 diabetes or hypertension require medical management, such as metformin or antihypertensives, alongside dietary and exercise interventions to control obesity and prevent complications like kidney damage or heart disease.

case_studies.vignette: A 15-year-old boy from a rural Indian setting presents to the clinic for follow-up after being identified as underweight during a school health camp three months ago. subtopics.subtopic_title: Special populations: adolescents with chronic illnesses or developmental delays / Guidelines for managing nutrition in adolescents with disabilities or developmental delays
subtopics.concept: Adolescents with chronic illnesses or developmental delays require tailored nutritional management, particularly when recovering from severe malnutrition or undergoing nutritional rehabilitation. Discharge criteria for adolescents in this context aim to ensure sufficient recovery and the ability to sustain progress at home. Although most guidelines on severe acute malnutrition (SAM) focus on children under five years, similar principles apply to older children and adolescents, with adjustments for age-appropriate indices. Anthropometric recovery is a key discharge criterion, emphasizing the need for nutritional status to improve from the "acute malnutrition" range to a safe level. For adolescents, BMI-for-age percentiles or z-scores are used as proxies since weight-for-height charts are not standardized beyond puberty. Discharge is typically considered when BMI-for-age rises above –2 SD (approximately the 5th percentile for age and sex) and is sustained for at least two weeks. For example, a 14-year-old girl admitted with SAM at a BMI of 14 (–3 SD) might be ready for discharge once her BMI reaches approximately 16.5 (above –2 SD) and shows an upward trend. Percent weight gain from admission is another criterion, especially when baseline height or BMI references are unavailable. A commonly used target is a weight gain of ≥15% from admission weight; for instance, an adolescent admitted at 30 kg would need to reach at least 34.5 kg to meet this benchmark. Bilateral pitting edema, a sign of kwashiorkor, must resolve completely and remain absent for at least two weeks before discharge to confirm sustained recovery. In addition to anthropometric criteria, clinical and functional recovery is essential. Adolescents should be clinically stable, with any intercurrent illnesses resolved or controlled, and demonstrate a good appetite, consuming regular balanced meals without intensive medical support. Transitioning from tube or nasogastric feeding to oral intake is necessary, alongside nutritional counseling for the adolescent and their caregivers to ensure proper feeding practices at home. Psychosocial readiness, particularly in cases of eating disorders, should also be addressed. Ultimately, discharge decisions should ensure the adolescent is no longer severely malnourished, has no edema, and exhibits a consistent trend of weight gain, with the capacity to maintain nutritional progress independently.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Special populations: adolescents with chronic illnesses (distinct from developmental delays)
subtopics.concept: Adolescents with chronic illnesses who have undergone treatment for severe malnutrition or nutritional rehabilitation, whether in inpatient or structured outpatient settings, require clearly defined discharge criteria to ensure sustained recovery at home. Although most guidelines for severe acute malnutrition (SAM) focus on children under five years, similar principles apply to older children and adolescents. Discharge is appropriate only after nutritional status has improved beyond the "acute malnutrition" range, medical complications are stabilized, and the adolescent and their caregiver can maintain nutritional progress independently. Key discharge criteria include anthropometric recovery, resolution of clinical signs such as edema, the ability to consume an adequate diet, and a demonstrated period of continuous weight gain. For anthropometric recovery, adolescents are considered for discharge when they are no longer acutely malnourished by age-appropriate indices. Since weight-for-height charts are not standardized beyond puberty, BMI-for-age percentiles or z-scores are used as proxies. An adolescent who was severely thin (e.g., BMI-for-age < –3 SD) may be deemed nutritionally recovered when their BMI-for-age rises above –2 SD (approximately the 5th percentile for age and sex) and is sustained for at least two weeks. For example, a 14-year-old girl admitted with a BMI of 14 (–3 SD) could be discharged once her BMI reaches approximately 16.5 (above –2 SD) and shows an upward trend. Alternatively, percent weight gain from admission is sometimes used, particularly when baseline height or BMI references are unavailable. A commonly used target is a ≥15% weight gain from admission weight; for instance, an adolescent admitted at 30 kg would need to reach at least 34.5 kg. Additionally, bilateral pitting edema, if present, must completely resolve and remain absent for at least two weeks to confirm stability, as early edema resolution can falsely suggest rapid weight gain. Clinically, the adolescent should be well, with resolved or controlled intercurrent illnesses such as infections or diarrhea. They must demonstrate a good appetite and consume adequate nutrition without intensive medical support, transitioning from therapeutic or tube feeding to regular balanced meals. Nutritional counseling for the adolescent and their family is essential to ensure proper feeding practices at home. Not specified in source: psychosocial readiness criteria.

She was previously admitted for severe malnutrition (BMI 13.8, <–3 SD) and treated with nutritional rehabilitation. Despite initial improvement, her BMI is currently 15.2 (–2.5 SD), and she has gained only 10% of her admission weight over 3 weeks. Her caregiver reports difficulty maintaining her nutritional plan due to financial constraints and irregular insulin availability. Examination reveals mild bilateral pedal edema and pallor, with no acute complications. Her fasting blood glucose is 240 mg/dL, and HbA1c is 10.5%. She has been on insulin therapy but with poor adherence. The family is concerned about her ability to sustain weight gain at home.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Adolescent-specific counselling techniques: practical approaches for adherence
subtopics.concept:
Adolescent-specific counselling techniques for adherence to physical activity in weight management require a tailored, motivational approach that aligns with the unique needs and preferences of this age group. Globally, including in India, 81% of school-going adolescents aged 11–17 fail to meet the WHO-recommended 60 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity daily, contributing to rising obesity and related health issues. Pediatricians must actively promote physical activity as a cornerstone of a healthy lifestyle, integrating it into adolescents' daily routines through enjoyable and sustainable methods. Counseling should emphasize the positive aspects of being active rather than framing it as a punishment or chore. Adolescents are more likely to adhere to physical activity when it aligns with their interests, such as sports (football, badminton, basketball), dance, swimming, cycling, or even brisk walking with friends. Counselors should begin by assessing the adolescent’s baseline activity levels and interests, asking questions like, “What do you like to do for fun? Do you have any sports or outdoor games you enjoy?”

The goal is to achieve at least 60 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity daily, as per WHO guidelines, with muscle- and bone-strengthening exercises included at least three days a week. Moderate activity is defined as being able to talk but not sing during it, while vigorous activity allows only a few words before pausing for breath. Examples of muscle-strengthening activities include squats, modified push-ups, yoga, or climbing. It is important to dispel the misconception that only structured exercise, like gym workouts, counts. Counselors can suggest creative alternatives, such as walking or cycling short distances, taking stairs instead of elevators, or dancing to music at home. For adolescents who find 60 continuous minutes challenging, breaking it into three 20-minute sessions throughout the day is acceptable. Step-count goals, like 10,000 steps daily, or fitness apps and active video games can also make physical activity more engaging and fun. Physical activity in weight management offers multiple benefits, including calorie burning, muscle building (which enhances basal metabolism), improved insulin sensitivity, and better psychological well-being, which can reduce stress-eating. Simplified explanations, such as “Exercise makes your body burn food better so it doesn’t turn into extra weight,” can help adolescents understand its importance and stay motivated.

subtopics.subtopic_title: Monitoring and follow-up strategies: tailored for individual and programmatic levels
subtopics.concept: Monitoring and follow-up strategies tailored for individual and programmatic levels in paediatric weight management must incorporate a structured yet flexible approach to physical activity. Physical activity is a cornerstone of weight management in adolescents, complementing dietary measures and offering extensive health benefits. Globally, including in India, approximately 81% of school-going adolescents aged 11–17 fail to meet the WHO-recommended 60 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity daily. This inactivity contributes significantly to obesity and related health issues. Therefore, paediatricians should actively promote physical activity as a lifestyle habit through motivational counselling and by linking adolescents with programmatic initiatives such as school sports or community programs. Counselling should begin with assessing the adolescent’s baseline activity levels and interests. Many adolescents may not engage in structured exercise but might enjoy activities like sports, dancing, swimming, or cycling. It is crucial to frame physical activity positively, emphasizing enjoyment rather than presenting it as a chore. For example, asking questions like, “What do you like to do for fun?” or “Do you enjoy any outdoor games?” can help identify activities that resonate with the adolescent. Highlight that any movement is better than none, including walking or biking to school, participating in physical education classes, or doing active household chores. The goal should align with WHO guidelines: at least 60 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity daily for 5–17-year-olds, with muscle- and bone-strengthening exercises on at least three days a week. Moderate activity can be explained as “when you can talk but not sing,” while vigorous activity means “you can’t say more than a few words without pausing for breath.” Muscle-strengthening exercises can include squats, push-ups, or yoga, which do not require gym access. To overcome barriers, it is essential to dispel misconceptions that only structured exercise counts. Suggest creative alternatives, such as walking short distances instead of using transport, taking stairs instead of lifts, or dancing to music at home. For adolescents who find a continuous 60-minute session challenging, breaking it into three 20-minute bursts throughout the day is equally effective. Step-count goals (e.g., 10,000 steps daily) or fitness apps can also motivate adolescents, turning activity into a game or challenge. Active video games or technology-based fitness tools may further enhance engagement. By integrating these strategies, physical activity can aid weight management by burning calories, building muscle to improve basal metabolism, enhancing insulin sensitivity, and supporting psychological well-being, which can reduce stress-eating.
